caption:
Table 2. The VAN achieves better 
results on the test set compared to the other approaches with a CER 
of 1.91% and a WER of 6.72%.

Table 2: Recognition results of the VAN and comparison with 
paragraph-level state-of-the-art approaches on the RIMES dataset.

Table 3: Comparison of the VAN with the state-of-the-art ap-
proaches at paragraph level on the IAM dataset.

Table 4. Our approach reaches 
a CER of 3.59% and a WER of 13.94%.
Table 4: VAN results for the READ 2016 dataset at paragraph level.

Table 6: Impact of the pretraining on lines for the VAN. Results 
are given on the test set of the IAM dataset.

Table 7: Comparison between cross-dataset pretraining and line-
level pretraining for the VAN. Results are given on the test sets.

Table 8: Comparison between fixed-stop, early-stop and learned-
stop approaches with the VAN on the test set of the IAM dataset.

Table 9. As one can see, the results are good for 
both tasks separately: we get 81.51% for the IoU and 85.09% for 
the mAP concerning the segmentation task; and a CER of 5.01% 
and a WER of 16.49% for the OCR. However, when we take the 
output of the segmentation as input for the OCR, it leads to a CER 
increase of 1.54 points. Indeed, the line segmentation errors induce 
recognition errors.
Table 9: Results of the two-step approach on the test set of IAM.

Table 10. First, one can notice that the VAN reaches a better 
CER of 4.45% compared to 6.55%. Prediction time is computed as 
the average prediction time, on the test set, to process a paragraph 
image. As one can see, even though the segmentation step is 
without recurrence, it requires much more time for prediction due 
to the formatting of the input required for the OCR, including the 
bounding boxes extraction from the original images. Moreover, it 
cumulates prediction times of the two models involved. Despite its 
recurrent process, the total prediction time for the VAN is shorter 
than that of the two-step approach since one iteration is very fast. 
In addition, it implies fewer parameters, this is notably due to 
the two models required by the two-step approach. Except for the 
training time, which is a bit higher for the VAN, it only provides 
advantages compared to the two-step approach.

Table 10: Comparison of the two-step approach with the Vertical 
Attention Network, results are given for the test set of the IAM 
dataset.

Table 11: VAN results at paragraph level with and without interline 
characters in ground truth for RIMES, IAM and READ 2016 
dataset.

Table 12: Comparison with the state of the art on the line-level 
RIMES dataset.

Table 13. We reach competitive results with a CER 
of 4.97% on the test set. Models proposed in

Table 15. The columns from 
left to right correspond respectively to the number of dropout layers 
per block (CB and DSCB), the type of dropout layer used (mix, 
standard or spatial), the associated dropout probabilities, the use of 
the diffuse option (using only one or all dropout layers per block) 
and the CER and WER for both models.

Table 15: Dropout strategy analysis. Results are given for the IAM 
test set.
